b|last=Scoles|first=Sarah|date=2016-08-26|work=WIRED|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} Vakoch responded to earlier theories that planets orbiting red dwarf stars like Proxima Centauri would not be suitable to sustain life because they would be tidally locked, with one side of the planet always facing the star and the other side facing away, meaning that "[o]ne side of the planet would be scorched, while the other side would be perpetually frozen." Vakoch argued that "new models of exoplanet atmospheres and oceans suggest that heat might be distributed around a tidally locked planet, leaving the door open for habitability. Even if the newly discovered exoplanet around Proxima Centauri is tidally locked, it could still be prime real estate for life." Nevertheless, Vakoch noted challenges to the habitability of this planet, saying "[t]he biggest downside of Proxima Centauri for alien hunters is that it's a flare star, dramatically and unpredictably varying in brightness over the course of a few minutes due to its magnetic activity."{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/proxima-b-earth-exoplanet-cousin-discovery-centauri-space-life/|title=Found in space: Planet Proxima b could be Earth's closest cousin|last=Mack|first=Eric|date=2016-08-24|work=CNET|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} Vakoch made similar comments about the potential habitability of exoplanets orbiting another red dwarf star, [[TRAPPIST-1]], noting "[b]ecause these planets have an orbit so close to the TRAPPIST-1 star, they are thought to be subject to the phenomenon of synchronized rotation."{{Cite news|url=https://ionline.sapo.pt/550616|title=Novo sistema planetário já tem site oficial (e posters)|last=Reis|first=Marta F.|date=2017-02-23|work=ionline|access-date=2017-04-23|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=pt}} He added that heat might be transferred on tidally locked planets, drawing a parallel to Earth: "[w]hen the Sun sets at night on the Golden Gate Bridge, I do not worry that San Francisco Bay will freeze." Vakoch's edited book ''Communication with Extraterrestrial Intelligence (CETI)'', based on papers presented at sessions he chaired at the 2010 NASA. Astrobiology Science Conference (AbSciCon),{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=June 2011|title=Communication with extraterrestrial intelligence. (Book review)|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-257994511.html|journal=Reference & Research Book News|volume=26|issue=3|pages=214|issn=0887-3763}} includes a section devoted to Active SETI.{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=2013-01-01|title=9. Changing Technologies|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/10948007.2013.750565|journal=Communication Booknotes Quarterly|volume=44|issue=1|pages=37|doi=10.1080/10948007.2013.750565|issn=1094-8007}} == Passive SETI == In 2010, Vakoch was one of the leaders of Project Dorothy, a multinational effort launched by Japanese astronomer Shin-ya Narusawa to observe several stars for signals from other civilizations to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of [[Project Ozma]], the first modern-day [[search for extraterrestrial intelligence]] (SETI).{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/11/06/AR2010110604127.html?sid=ST2010110604135|title=Observatories on 5 continents to scan skies for extraterrestrial life|last=Kaufman|first=Marc|date=2010-11-07|work=The Washington Post|access-date=2017-04-12|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}} Telling ''[[The Washington Post]]'' about the Project Dorothy observations, Vakoch said "[w]hat this weekend really does is begin the process of making it possible to track a possible SETI signal around the globe," and he added "[i]f a signal is detected, it has to be confirmed and followed, and now we're setting up a network to do that." Vakoch participated in the earliest SETI observations of the anomalous star [[KIC 8462852|KIC 8452852]], also known as Tabby's Star, which some astronomers have hypothesized may be orbited by an alien megastructure.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/search-for-alien-laser-pulses-from-a-strange-star-system-reports-back/|title=Search for alien laser pulses from a strange star system reports back|last=Mack|first=Eric|date=2016-06-27|work=CNET|access-date=2017-04-19|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} The observations were conducted at optical frequencies at METI's Boquete Optical SETI Observatory in Panama,{{Cite journal|last=Schuetz|first=Marlin|last2=Vakoch|first2=Douglas A.|last3=Shostak|first3=Seth|last4=Richards|first4=Jon|date=2016-01-01|title=Optical SETI Observations of the Anomalous Star KIC 8462852|url=http://stacks.iop.org/2041-8205/825/i=1/a=L5|journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters|language=en|volume=825|issue=1|pages=L5|doi=10.3847/2041-8205/825/1/L5|issn=2041-8205|arxiv=1512.02388|bibcode=2016ApJ...825L...5S}} and also at radio frequencies at the [[SETI Institute]]’s [[Allen Telescope Array]] in the United States.{{Cite web|url=http://www.msn.com/en-gb/news/science/scientists-are-days-from-finding-out-if-that-mysterious-star-could-actually-harbor-aliens/ar-BBml63Z?li=AA9SkIr|title=Scientists are days from finding out if that mysterious star could actually harbor aliens|last=Orwig|first=Jessica|date=2015-10-23|website=www.msn.com|publisher=MSN|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-10}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/no-word-from-supposed-alien-megastructure-yet/|title=No word yet from supposed alien megastructure|last=Schupak|first=Amanda|date=2015-11-10|work=CBS News|access-date=2017-04-10|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}{{Cite journal|last=Harp|first=G. R.|last2=Richards|first2=Jon|last3=Shostak|first3=Seth|last4=Tarter|first4=J. C.|last5=Vakoch|first5=Douglas A.|last6=Munson|first6=Chris|date=2016-01-01|title=Radio SETI Observations of the Anomalous Star KIC 8462852|url=http://stacks.iop.org/0004-637X/825/i=2/a=155|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|language=en|volume=825|issue=2|pages=155|doi=10.3847/0004-637X/825/2/155|issn=0004-637X|arxiv=1511.01606|bibcode=2016ApJ...825..155H}} No indications of artificial signals were detected at either facility: "The hypothesis of an alien megastructure around KIC 8462852 is rapidly crumbling apart," he said, adding "[w]e found no evidence of an advanced civilization beaming intentional laser signals toward Earth.”{{Cite news|url=http://www.iflscience.com/space/there-definitely-no-intellligent-life-around-alien-megastructure-star/|title=There Is Definitely No Intelligent Life Around The 'Alien Megastructure' Star|last=O'Callaghan|first=Jonathan|date=2015-11-12|work=IFLScience|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} Vakoch argued that the name Tabby's Star is sexist because stars named after male astronomers have not used their first names.{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/kic-8462852-no-signals-alien-megastructure-star-big-breakthrough-hunt-et-1567900|title=KIC 8462852: No signals from 'alien megastructure' star but a big breakthrough in hunt for ET|last=Vakoch|first=Douglas|date=2016-07-29|work=International Business Times|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Instead, Vakoch suggests that KIC 8452852 should be referred to as [[Boyajian's Star|Boyajian's Star]], in recognition of [[Tabetha S. Boyajian]], who led the team discovering the anomalous dimming. When a candidate SETI signal from the direction of the star [[HD 164595]] was first announced by Russian astronomers, Vakoch told ''[[CNN]]'' that "[t]he signal from HD 164595 is intriguing, because it comes from the vicinity of a sun-like star, and if it's artificial, its strength is great enough that it was clearly made by a civilization with capabilities beyond those of humankind."{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/08/30/health/seti-signal-hd-164595-alien-civilization/index.html|title=Can you hear me now? 'Strong signal' from star sparks alien speculation|last=Griffiths|first=James|date=2016-08-30|website=CNN|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-16}} Given the strength of the signal detected from Russia, Vakoch said we could determine how advanced the transmutting civilization is if the signal is artificial, using the [[Kardashev scale|Kardashev Scale]] that hypothesizes Type I, Type II, and Type III civilizations: "If the signal from HD 164595 is from a civilization that is radiating out electromagnetic signals in all directions, that takes tremendous energy -- the energy of an entire star, represented by a Type II civilization," Vakoch told ''[[CNET]]''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/alien-signal-likely-isnt-but-if-it-is-theyre-way-smarter-than-us/|title='Alien' signal likely isn't, but if it is, they're way smarter than us|last=Mack|first=Eric|date=2016-08-30|work=CNET|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} “If it’s focused at Earth, then the civilization doesn’t need to have quite that great of a capability. It could be a Type I,” Vakoch said.{{Cite news|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/20442-kardashev-scale-seti-signal|title=What the Kardashev Scale Says About SETI Signals|last=Patel|first=Neel V.|date=2016-08-31|work=Inverse|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} "Humanity is currently somewhere between Type 0 and Type I," he explained. Vakoch said that "[i]n the past, plans for SETI follow-up observations have focused on confirmation of the original signal, seeking a repeat signal at the same frequency. That’s a critical step for confirmation – and we don’t yet have evidence that this sort of follow-up has happened for HD 164595."{{Cite news|url=http://www.geekwire.com/2016/signal-seti-interest-hd164595/|title=They’re not saying it’s aliens, but signal traced to sunlike star sparks SETI interest|last=Boyle|first=Alan|date=2017-08-26|work=GeekWire|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} Vakoch said that METI's optical SETI observatory in Panama would be able observe HD 164595 "about an hour shortly after sunset each night,” weather permitting,{{Cite news|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/2103604-mysterious-signal-unlikely-to-be-aliens-after-seti-draws-a-blank/|title=Mysterious signal unlikely to be aliens after SETI draws a blank|last=Hall|first=Shannon|date=2016-08-30|work=New Scientist|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} telling ''[[CNN]]'' that they would be "searching for any brief laser pulses that might be sent as a beacon from advanced extraterrestrials." Because the Panama observatory is designed to avoid [[False positives and false negatives|false positives]], “[i]f we get a signal there, that’s a really strong sign we’ve really discovered extraterrestrial life,” Vakoch said, adding “[n]ow, we don’t expect to find that, but we’re going to do our due diligence. This is the sort of thing that, internally, we do all the time.”{{Cite news|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/20392-hype-check-is-russian-radio-signal-really-that-special|title=Hype Check: Is That Russian SETI Signal Really Aliens?|last=Medrano|first=Kastalia|date=2016-08-30|work=Inverse|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} While the original signal from the direction of HD 164595 was detected at radio frequencies, Vakoch argued for expanding the search to other frequencies: "if this were really a signal from extraterrestrials, we'd want to survey the target star across as much of the electromagnetic spectrum as we could." Vakoch was not optimistic about detecting a signal from HD 164595 but he said that follow-up observations help prepare for detecting a real signal: “I think the likely outcome of this is that there’s no indication that it’s ET, but it provides a critical preparation for a day we may really discover intelligence out there,” he told ''[[New Scientist]]''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/2102970-mysterious-seti-signal-sends-alien-hunting-telescopes-scrambling/|title=Mysterious SETI signal sends alien-hunting telescopes scrambling|last=Hall|first=Shannon|date=2016-08-29|work=New Scientist|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} Vakoch argues that replication of a putative SETI signal is essential for confirmation, and the lack of such replication means that past signals such as the [[Wow! signal]] have little credibility.{{Cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/wissenschaft/article1439767/Welche-Sprache-sprechen-Ausserirdische.html|title=Welche Sprache sprechen Außerirdische?|last=Marsiske|first=Hans-Arthur|date=2007-09-12|website=Die Welt|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-09}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.astrowatch.net/2015/07/we-could-find-aliens-any-day-now-seti.html|title=We Could Find Aliens Any Day Now: SETI Scientists Discuss Extraterrestrial Life Hunting|last=|first=|date=2015-07-09|website=www.astrowatch.net|publisher=Astrowatch|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-09}} "Without corroboration from an independent observatory, a putative signal from extraterrestrials doesn't have a lot of credibility," he told ''[[CNN]]''. He urged that HD 164595 should not be treated as a plausible candidate without further confirmation: “Assuming we don’t find any evidence of a transmitting civilization as we conduct follow-up observations, the worst outcome would be to turn HD 164595 into another Wow signal – seen once, never confirmed, but lurking in the imagination as perhaps really a message from another world. Unless we can observe another similar signal from the vicinity of this star, we need to dismiss the May 2015 signal as a spurious result, and not wishfully hope it was really from ET.”{{Cite news|url=http://www.geekwire.com/2016/still-no-aliens-lessons-learned-strange-radio-signal-seti-quest/|title=Still no aliens in the SETI quest: Lessons learned from that strange radio signal|last=Boyle|first=Alan|date=2016-08-30|work=GeekWire|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} When two Canadian astronomers argued that they potentially discovered 234 extraterrestrial civilizations through analysis of the [[Sloan Digital Sky Survey]] database, Vakoch doubted their explanation for their findings, noting that it would be unusual for all of these stars to pulse at exactly the same frequency unless they were part a coordinated network: “If you take a step back,” he said, “that would mean you have 234 independent stars that all decided to transmit the same way.”{{Cite news|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/22876-234-pulsing-stars-aren-t-aliens-still-mysterious|title=Those 234 Pulsing Stars Probably Aren’t Aliens, But They're Still a Complex Mystery|last=Patel|first=Neel V.|date=2016-10-28|work=Inverse|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} “The general mindset in SETI is that, before you say it’s an extraterrestrial intelligence, you have to think really creatively about what the natural explanations might be—and I think it’s way too early in the game to jump to the conclusion that it’s extraterrestrial intelligence,” Vakoch said.{{Cite news|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/87961/have-we-detected-hundreds-signals-extraterrestrial-life|title=Have We Detected Hundreds of Signals From Extraterrestrial Life?|last=Falk|first=Dan|date=2016-10-25|work=mental_floss|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} When astronomers announced in January 2017 that the [[fast radio burst]] FRB 121102 comes from a [[dwarf galaxy]] almost three billion light years from Earth, Vakoch said that METI was using the Boquete Optical SETI Observatory in Panama to search for brief laser pulses from the same target. "I'm not holding my breath, and I'm not expecting to find any evidence of ET, but the follow-up is straightforward, so we'll make the observations out of due diligence," he told ''[[CNET]]'', adding "[s]o far we've found nothing that looks like the telltale sign of extraterrestrial technology."{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/frb-121102-fast-radio-bursts-aliens-seti-meti-galaxy/|title=Scientists search for aliens in galaxy sending weird radio signals|last=Mack|first=Eric|date=2017-01-04|work=CNET|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} After the star Wolf 1061 was announced to be orbited by three "super-Earths," including Wolf 1061c that lies in the star's habitable zone, Vakoch reported that METI had on four separate occasions observed the star for brief laser pulses from its optical SETI observatory in Panama.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/scientists-are-checking-a-nearby-exoplanet-for-alien-transmissions/|title=Scientists are checking a nearby exoplanet for alien transmissions|last=Mack|first=Eric|date=2017-01-20|work=CNET|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} "[T]he fact that there’s a roughly Earth-like planet in the habitable zone of a star so close to our own solar system is a good omen as we continue our search for life on other planets,” he told ''[[Gizmodo]]''.{{Cite news|url=https://gizmodo.com/scientists-are-searching-for-life-on-this-nearby-exopla-1791442917|title=Scientists Are Searching For Life On This Nearby Exoplanet|last=Paoletta|first=Rae|date=2017-01-20|work=Gizmodo|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} "So far, we've found no indications of advanced technologies in this promising exoplanet just 14 light-years from Earth," he said. When unusual radio signals were reported in the vicinity of the red dwarf [[Ross 128]], Vakoch noted that this star had already been searched for brief laser pulses five times in the past from METI's optical SETI observatory in Panama, with no evidence of extraterrestrial technology detected. He observed that the signals detected from Ross 128 did not fit the expected profile of a radio signal from extraterrestrials, and the signals had not repeated, which is further reason not to treat these signals as credible evidence of extraterrestrial intelligence.{{Cite news|url=https://www.space.com/37516-strange-radio-signals-red-dwarf-star.html|title=Weird Radio Signals Detected from Nearby Red Dwarf Star|last=Wall|first=Mike|date=2017-07-17|work=Space.com|access-date=2018-02-11|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} When China's [[Five hundred meter Aperture Spherical Telescope|Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical Telescope]] (FAST) went online, Vakoch told ''[[CNN]]'' that "China's latest telescope will be able to look faster and further than past searches for extraterrestrial intelligence."{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/09/21/health/china-fast-telescope-search-for-aliens/index.html|title=China's giant space telescope starts search for alien life|last=Hunt|first=Katie|date=2016-09-21|website=CNN|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-16}} He told ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'' that FAST is a “game-changer in the search for life in the universe".{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/09/24/a-game-changer-in-the-search-for-aliens-china-switches-on-worlds/|title=A ‘game-changer in the search for aliens’: China switches on world’s biggest telescope|last=Connor|first=Neil|date=2016-09-24|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-GB}} "FAST's innovative design and huge collecting area give it unsurpassed speed and sensitivity, making it vital to the search for extraterrestrial intelligence in the coming decades," Vakoch told [[Xinhua News Agency|''Xinhua'']], adding "[w]e can expect China to become a world leader in the search for extraterrestrial intelligence because of its demonstrated commitment in building FAST."{{Cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-09/25/c_135712298.htm|title=China's giant telescope may lead to 'discoveries beyond wildest imagination': U.S. expert|last=|first=|date=2016-09-25|website=news.xinhuanet.com|publisher=Xinhua|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-16}} The telescope will study the distribution of hydrogen to understand the origin of the universe, and Vakoch says that "[b]ecause of FAST's incredible sensitivity, it will be able to chart the hydrogen distribution even in far flung galaxies." He expected that FAST would lead to "a dramatic increase in the number and variety of pulsars discovered." Vakoch also noted the limitations of the telescope, saying "FAST may help explain the origin of the universe and the structure of the cosmos, but it won't provide warning of Earth-bound asteroids that could destroy human civilization." When plans were announced to build the [[Qitai Radio Telescope]] (QTT), which would be the largest steerable radio telescope in the world, Vakoch noted its ability to pinpoint stars that are not accessible to FAST.{{Cite news|url=https://www.space.com/39508-china-worlds-largest-steerable-radio-telescope.html|title=China Plans to Build the World's Largest Steerable Radio Telescope|last=Atkinson|first=Nancy|date=2018-01-29|work=Space.com|access-date=2018-02-11|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} He noted the QTT could support the search for extraterrestrial life by scanning interstellar space for complex organic molecules, as well as searching for narrowband techno-signatures indicative of extraterrestrial intelligence. Because FAST and the QTT can both search within the "[[Water hole (radio)|water hole]]" that SETI scientists have long preferred, Vakoch told ''[[CNET]]'' that each observatory could confirm interesting signals detected by the other observatory within this frequency range.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/radio-telescope-china-qtt-alien-signals/|title=New biggest radio telescope to help detect alien signals|last=Mack|first=Eric|date=2018-01-17|work=CNET|access-date=2018-02-11|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Vakoch suggests that the detection of extraterrestrials in a standard SETI scenario may be less clear-cut than usually assumed: "I think the assumption that one day someone is going to announce that we’ve discovered extraterrestrial intelligence, and now the world knows, is a fallacy, because there’s going to be much more ambiguity in the process."{{Cite journal|last=Folger|first=Tim|date=January 2011|title=Contact: The Day After|url=http://www.timfolger.net/seti.pdf|journal=Scientific American|volume=|pages=35}} “Unlike Hollywood movies, where you get a quick 'yes or no' about a possible signal from aliens,” Vakoch told ''[[Universe Today]]'', “the real SETI confirmation process takes some time. It’s easy to think that all we need to do is get on the phone with an astronomer at another location, and we’re all set. But even when colleagues at other facilities are willing to observe, they may face technical limitations.”{{Cite news|url=https://www.universetoday.com/130550/going-viral-alien-signals-get-everyone-excited/|title=Going Viral: Why Alien Signals Get Everyone Excited|last=Atkinson|first=Nancy|date=2016-08-31|work=Universe Today|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} He also assumes it may take some time to decode any message: "I don't think we're going to understand immediately what they have to say," he told ''[[ABC News]].''{{Cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/story?id=98628&page=1|title=Waiting for Contact With Alien Life|last=Amos|first=Deborah|date=2001-04-23|website=ABC News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-10}} “There’s going to be a lot of guesswork in trying to interpret another civilization," he told ''[[Science Friday]]'', adding that "[i]n some ways, any message we get from an extraterrestrial will be like a cosmic [[Rorschach test|Rorschach ink blot test]].”{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencefriday.com/articles/what-happens-if-we-detect-extraterrestrial-intelligence/|title=What Happens if We Detect Extraterrestrial Intelligence?|last=Leibach|first=Julie|date=2016-11-30|work=Science Friday|access-date=2017-04-19|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} Vakoch contends that it is essential to expand an understanding of SETI beyond the technology needed to search by also re-examining assumptions about the nature of intelligence, which was the motivation for the METI workshop, “The Intelligence of SETI: Cognition and Communication in Extraterrestrial Intelligence,”{{Cite news|url=http://www.airspacemag.com/daily-planet/conversing-et-180959306/|title=Conversing With E.T.|last=Schulze-Makuch|first=Dirk|date=2016-06-03|work=Air & Space Magazine|access-date=2017-04-09|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} held in San Juan, Puerto Rico on May 18, 2016.{{Cite news|url=https://www.universetoday.com/129092/alien-minds-extraterrestrial-civilizations-likely/|title=Alien Minds I: Are Extraterrestrial Civilizations Likely to Evolve?|last=Patton|first=Paul|date=2016-05-24|work=Universe Today|access-date=2017-04-19|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} "By studying the variety of intelligence found on Earth," Vakoch said, "we can gain new insights into sending messages to life on other planets."{{Cite news|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/15804-how-do-we-talk-to-aliens-scientists-meet-in-puerto-rico-to-hash-it-out|title=How Do We Talk to Aliens? Scientists Meet in Puerto Rico to Hash It Out|last=Patel|first=Neel V.|date=2016-05-18|work=Inverse|access-date=2017-04-19|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} He called for "rethinking what SETI means," saying "what we haven't caught up with is the real understanding of intelligence."{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/alien-intelligence-life-universe-may-be-abundant-will-it-ever-communicate-us-1561088|title=Alien life in the universe may well be abundant, but will it ever communicate with us?|last=Osborne|first=Hannah|date=2016-05-20|work=International Business Times UK|access-date=2017-04-19}} Vakoch told the [[International Business Times]] that "[i]n this new approach, we're putting the intelligence back into SETI." He argues that the fact that extraterrestrial intelligence may rely on different senses than humans adds to the complexity of interspecies communication.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailymotion.com/video/xb23qg_cosmic-connexion-interviews_tech|title=Cosmic Connexion : Interviews - vidéo|last=|first=|date=2009-11-06|website=Dailymotion|language=fr|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-09}}{{Cite journal|last=Sutton|first=Jon|date=October 2015|title=What would you say to an alien?|url=https://thepsychologist.bps.org.uk/volume-28/october-2015/interview-what-would-you-say-alien|journal=The Psychologist|volume=28|pages=800–803}} ==Interstellar message design== Vakoch "leads an international group of scientists, artists and scholars from the humanities, as they ponder how we could communicate what it’s like to be human across the vast distances of interstellar space."{{Cite news|url=https://www.ncronline.org/blogs/eco-catholic/how-do-we-craft-message-stars|title=How do we craft a message to the stars?|last=Heffern|first=Rich|date=2010-12-30|work=National Catholic Reporter|access-date=2017-04-10|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} He advocates creating interstellar messages that begin with concepts shared by humans and extraterrestrials, such as basic mathematics and science and building on these shared concepts to express content that may be distinctly human.{{Cite news|url=http://www.space.com/8120-earth-respond-aliens.html|title=How Should Earth Respond When Aliens Say Hello?|last=Moskowitz|first=Clara|date=2010-04-01|work=Space.com|access-date=2017-04-09|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} He argues that while mathematics and science provide the best starting point for interstellar messages, it is possible that extraterrestrial mathematics and science may vary significantly from human mathematics and science. He notes that on Earth both Euclidean and non-Euclidean geometries provide internally consistent frameworks for understanding the world, but they vary in their foundational assumptions.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2013/11/enders-game-alien-communication/|title=What Ender’s Game Gets Right About Communicating With Aliens|last=Mann|first=Adam|date=2013-11-01|work=WIRED|access-date=2017-04-09|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} Vakoch provided an overview of interstellar message design at the 2012 TEDx Nashville. In contrast to the images included on the [[Voyager Golden Record]] that emphasized the positive aspects of life on Earth, Vakoch proposes that we should be honest about human frailties.{{Cite news|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn16981-why-we-shouldnt-hide-our-problems-from-et/|title=Why we shouldn’t hide our problems from ET|last=Vakoch|first=Douglas|date=2009-04-18|work=New Scientist|access-date=2017-04-12|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}{{Cite journal|last=Vakoch|first=Douglas|date=2009|title=Honest Exchanges with ET|url=|journal=New Scientist|volume=202|issue=2705|pages=22–23|bibcode=2009NewSc.202...22T|doi=10.1016/S0262-4079(09)60916-7}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/wissenschaft/natur/kommunikation-mit-ausserirdischen-die-nackte-wahrheit-a-620011.html|title=Kommunikation mit Außerirdischen: Die nackte Wahrheit|last=|first=|date=2009-04-20|website=SPIEGEL ONLINE|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-12}} He suggests that the most informative things that humankind can convey to an advanced civilization are the struggles humankind is going through as an adolescent technological civilization.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20141112-will-et-understand-our-messages|title=Are we sending aliens the right messages?|last=Logan|first=Tracey|date=2014-11-12|website=BBC Future|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-09}} Vakoch argues that if we contact other civilizations, they will likely be thousands or millions of years older than humanity's civilization, meaning the extraterrestrial civilization would have greater stability.{{Cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/wissenschaft/weltall/seti-vs-meti-die-debatte-um-nachrichten-an-ausserirdische-a-1018469.html|title=Nachrichten ins All: Was, wenn jemand antwortet?|last=Becker|first=Markus|date=2015-02-14|website=SPIEGEL ONLINE|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-12}} "Perhaps it is not the beauty of our symphonies that will set us apart from extraterrestrials, nor our moral perfection – living true to our ideals of altruism. If we wish to convey what it is about us that is distinctive, it may be our weakness, our fears, our unknowing – and yet a willingness to forge ahead to attempt contact in spite of this," Vakoch told ''[[The Psychologist (magazine)|The Psychologist]]''. Vakoch calls for increasing the range of people participating in interstellar message design, and he led a workshop in Paris in 2002 on the interface of art and science in interstellar messages.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/what-would-iyou-i-say-to-et/|title=What Would ''You '' Say To E.T.?|last=Collins|first=Dan|date=2002-03-26|work=CBS News|access-date=2017-04-10|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|publisher=Reuters|language=en}} Speaking to ''[[Reuters]]'' on the day of the meeting, he said "Today the focus has been on whether we can explain something about our aesthetic sensibilities. Is there something about art that is either universal or that can be taught, step by step, to another intelligence?" He chaired a follow-up meeting in Paris in 2003 called "Encoding Altruism," focusing on communicating altruism in interstellar messages.{{Cite news|url=http://greatergood.berkeley.edu/article/item/alien_kindness|title=Alien Kindness|last=Dixon|first=Alex|date=2008-03-01|work=Greater Good|access-date=2017-04-09|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.exobiologie.fr/index.php/vulgarisation/astronomie-vulgarisation/paradoxe-de-fermi-et-recherche-dintelligences-extraterrestres-que-faire-en-france/|title=Paradoxe de Fermi et recherche d’intelligences extraterrestres. Que faire en France ?|last=Labèque|first=Alain|date=2006-06-08|website=www.exobiologie.fr|publisher=Société Française d'Exobiologie|language=fr-FR|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-09}} Vakoch stressed that the goal of the workshop was not to present an image of humanity as unambiguously altruistic.{{Cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/wissenschaft/weltall/interview-zu-alien-botschaften-wir-moechten-mitteilen-dass-wir-friedliche-absichten-haben-a-242311.html|title=Interview zu Alien-Botschaften: 'Wir möchten mitteilen, dass wir friedliche Absichten haben'|last=|first=|date=2003-03-28|website=SPIEGEL ONLINE|language=de|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-09}} "Previous attempts at communication, such as on the Voyager space probe, presented the positive side of human beings," Vakoch told ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'', adding "There's been no poverty, or war, or the nuclear mushroom cloud. We're trying to start a tough dialogue about how we describe the breadth of human experience."{{Cite journal|last=Whitfield|first=John|date=2003-03-21|title=SETI workshops selfless message|url=http://www.nature.com/news/2003/030317/full/news030317-11.html|journal=Nature News|language=en|doi=10.1038/news030317-11}} Vakoch also led meetings attended by anthropologists and sociologists,{{Cite news|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn13096-et-too-bored-by-earth-transmissions-to-respond/|title=ET too bored by Earth transmissions to respond|last=Simonite|first=Tom|date=2007-12-18|work=New Scientist|access-date=2017-04-09|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} and he advocates interstellar messages that capture the diversity of human cultures.{{Cite journal|last=Vakoch|first=Douglas A|date=1998-05-01|title=The dialogic model: representing human diversity in messages to extraterrestrials1|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0094576598000307|journal=Acta Astronautica|volume=42|issue=10–12|pages=705–710|doi=10.1016/S0094-5765(98)00030-7|bibcode=1998AcAau..42..705V}} In 2009 Vakoch launched an internet-based project called ''Earth Speaks'' to collect messages from people around the world that they would want to send to extraterrestrial intelligence.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/jun/07/science/sci-aliens7|title=How do you greet an extraterrestrial?|last=Johnson|first=John, Jr.|date=2009-06-07|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-04-09|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.chronicle.com/blogs/wiredcampus/researchers-at-seti-hope-to-make-a-good-first-impression-with-your-help/7210|title=Researchers at SETI Hope to Make a Good First Impression, With Your Help|last=Hendry|first=Erica R.|date=2009-06-11|website=|publisher=The Chronicle of Higher Education|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-09}} "One of the strongest themes we see in ‘Earth Speaks’ is a concern with our current environmental crisis," Vakoch said.{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.sg/uk-collaboration-is-set-to-transmit-questions-into-space-2016-2/|title=Humans are about to send one of our most elaborate message yet into deep space|last=Orwig|first=Jessica|date=2016-02-13|work=Business Insider|access-date=2017-04-09|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} Among the messages gathered in the ''Earth Speaks'' project, "the loudest message is people asking for help," Vakoch told ''[[The New York Times]]''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/12/sunday-review/messages-to-et.html|title=Messages to E.T.|last=Roberts|first=Sam|date=2012-02-11|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-04-09|issn=0362-4331}} "We gathered messages from people in over 80 countries around the world, and really sort of got the pulse of what people think we should say to other civilizations. Sometimes it maps on to what scientists are saying, suggesting we should start with math and science, and a lot of the greetings are just basic greetings of 'Hello, from the people of planet Earth,'" Vakoch told the [[Observer Media|''Observer'']], adding that "[o]ne of the most interesting findings are that sometimes people have said if we find another civilization beyond Earth, it will diminish the differences we see between cultures and ethnicities here on Earth, because they’ll be so minuscule compared to the differences between ourselves and extraterrestrials. The exercise of preparing for a reply seems to be furthering that process of seeing our commonalities."{{Cite news|url=http://observer.com/2015/10/bizarre-space-objects-could-be-sign-of-alien-civilization/|title=Bizarre Space Objects Could Be Sign of Alien Civilization|last=Sainato|first=Michael|date=2015-10-28|work=Observer|access-date=2017-04-19|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} Vakoch said that ''Earth Speaks'' messages differed from greetings in the [[Voyager Golden Record]] insofar as the ''Earth Speaks'' messages included negative depictions of life on Earth.{{Cite news|url=http://www.zeit.de/online/2009/31/vakoch-all-botschaften|title=Suche nach Außerirdischen: E-Mail ins All|last=Rauner|first=Max|date=2009-08-08|work=Die Zeit|access-date=2017-04-12|issn=0044-2070}} The ''Earth Speaks'' project was also expanded to Spanish-speaking respondents as ''La Tierra Habla''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2011/03/27/sem-norma.html|title=La Tierra habla|last=Jiménez|first=Norma Ávila|date=2011-03-27|website=www.jornada.unam.mx|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-09}} Vakoch suggests that even if we never make contact with extraterrestrial intelligence, the process of creating interstellar messages is valuable,{{Cite web|url=https://www.heise.de/tp/features/Nur-Lauschen-oder-auch-Senden-3408660.html|title=Nur Lauschen oder auch Senden?|last=Marsiske|first=Hans-Arthur|date=2006-11-08|website=Telepolis|language=de-DE|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-09}} for example, by encouraging people to reflect on what they most care about., He judges the proposal to send extraterrestrials a "digital data dump" of the full contents of the internet as "ugly,"{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-16273512|title=Alien hunters: What if ET ever phones our home?|last=Palmer|first=Jason|date=2012-01-16|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-04-09|language=en-GB}} though he says there is no harm in doing this unless interstellar communication is a form of commerce, in which case we may shortchange future generations of humans by giving away everything from the outset of an interstellar exchange.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p00mv18b|title=Seti, the past, present and future, Discovery - BBC World Service|last=Palmer|first=Jason|date=2012-01-16|website=BBC|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-09}} In contrast, Vakoch advocates sending interstellar messages that convey aesthetic concepts.{{Cite news|url=http://mainepublic.org/post/how-do-we-explain-human-aesthetics-extraterrestrial-civilizations#stream/0|title=How Do We Explain Human Aesthetics to Extraterrestrial Civilizations?|last=|first=|date=2012-11-03|work=Maine Public Radio|access-date=2017-04-09|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} His own interstellar messages have been exhibited at the [[Chabot Space and Science Center]]{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/in_depth/sci_tech/2000/dot_life/2023019.stm|title=How would we answer the phone if ET called us?|last=Shiels|first=Maggie|date=2002-06-03|website=news.bbc.co.uk|publisher=BBC News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-09}} and at the [[Maison européenne de la photographie|Maison Européenne de la Photographie]], the latter in his @rt outsiders 2003 exhibit on interstellar messages about altruism titled "Le sacrifice de soi."{{Cite web|url=http://www.art-outsiders.net/archive_2003/index-en.html|title=Festival @rt Outsiders 2003|last=|first=|date=|website=www.art-outsiders.net|pages=Gallery|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-09}} When asked by ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' magazine what message he would want to send to extraterrestrials, Vakoch responded, "I would want to ask an extraterrestrial: What do you care about? What makes you happy?"{{Cite journal|last=American Association for the Advancement of Science|first=|date=2015-02-20|title=This week's section|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/347/6224/808|journal=Science|language=en|volume=347|issue=6224|pages=808–811|doi=10.1126/science.347.6224.808|issn=0036-8075}}{{Cite web|url=https://vine.co/v/OPrA5XenvDD|title=Vine|last=Vakoch|first=Douglas|date=2015-02-13|website=Vine|publisher=Science Magazine|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-09}} == Societal impact of SETI and astrobiology == Vakoch argues for the importance of identifying analogues for making contact with extraterrestrials, because humans do not have direct access to extraterrestrial civilizations in advance of contact. He suggests that the challenges of decoding the [[Rosetta Stone]] may provide insights into the challenges facing SETI scientists if they detect an information-rich signal from another civilization.{{Cite web|url=http://motherboard.vice.com/read/understanding-alien-messages-may-be-no-different-than-decoding-the-rosetta-stone|title=Understanding Alien Messages May Be No Different Than Decoding the Rosetta Stone|last=Koebler|first=Jason|date=2014-05-24|website=Motherboard|language=en-us|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-10}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/catalyst/stories/s656137.htm|title=Are We Alone? (part 2)|last=|first=|date=2002-08-22|website=www.abc.net.au|publisher=Catalyst, ABC TV Science|language=en-au|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-10}} Vakoch and Yuh-shiow Lee conducted a survey to assess people's reactions to receiving a message from extraterrestrials, including their judgments about likelihood that extraterrestrials would be malevolent.{{Cite journal|last=Vakoch|first=D. A|last2=Lee|first2=Y. -S|date=2000-06-01|title=Reactions to receipt of a message from extraterrestrial intelligence: a cross-cultural empirical study|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Yuh_Shiow_Lee/publication/222560399_Reactions_to_receipt_of_a_message_from_extraterrestrial_intelligence_a_cross-cultural_empirical_study/links/5551c5a408ae93634eca2405.pdf|journal=Acta Astronautica|volume=46|issue=10–12|pages=737–744|doi=10.1016/S0094-5765(00)00041-2|bibcode=2000AcAau..46..737V}} "Chinese participants were able to imagine contact would lead to both risks and benefits,” Vakoch told ''[[The Washington Post]]'', while Americans imagined the discovery of extraterrestrials would be "all good or all bad, but not both."{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/speaking-of-science/wp/2017/12/04/how-will-humanity-react-to-alien-life-psychologists-have-some-predictions/|title=How will humanity react to alien life? Psychologists have some predictions|last=Guarino|first=Ben|date=2017-12-04|work=The Washington Post|access-date=2018-02-11|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} "People who view the world as a hostile place are more likely to think extraterrestrials will be hostile," Vakoch told ''[[USA Today]]''.{{Cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/tech/science/space/2010-11-24-UFO24_ST_N.htm|title=Probe into alien life forms picks up steam|last=Keen|first=Judy|date=2010-11-23|work=USA Today|access-date=2017-04-11|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Vakoch says the majority of people already believe in the existence of extraterrestrial intelligence.{{Cite news|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/how-would-you-react-if-we-discovered-alien-life-180959286/?no-ist|title=How Would You React If We Discovered Alien Life?|last=Levine|first=David|date=2016-06-07|work=Smithsonian|access-date=2017-04-09|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} Vakoch argues that the discovery of extraterrestrial intelligence would not diminish the uniqueness of humankind.{{Cite web|url=http://interfaithradio.org/Story_Details/Would_Alien_Contact_Change_Religion_on_Earth_|title=Would Alien Contact Change Religion on Earth?|last=|first=|date=2013-12-13|website=Interfaith Voices|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-09}} Vakoch suggests that learning about an extraterrestrial civilization would increase people's self-understanding.{{Cite news|url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/religionandethics/2016/04/29/extraterrestrial-intelligent-life/30121/|title=Extraterrestrial Intelligent Life|last=|first=|date=2016-04-29|work=Religion & Ethics NewsWeekly|access-date=2017-04-09|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|publisher=PBS|language=en-US}} He argues that it is not likely that the discovery of extraterrestrial life will impact religious beliefs,{{Cite news|url=http://www.space.com/16285-alien-life-discovery-religion-impact.html|title=Religion Would Likely Survive Alien Life Discovery|last=Wall|first=Mike|date=2012-06-25|work=Space.com|access-date=2017-04-09|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} and he doubts that humans would be inclined to adopt extraterrestrial religions,{{Cite web|url=http://www.scienceandreligiontoday.com/2010/03/18/would-intelligent-aliens-undermine-god/|title=Would Intelligent Aliens Undermine God?|last=Kuhn|first=Robert Lawrence|date=2010-03-18|website=Science and Religion Today|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-09}} telling ''[[ABC News]]'' "I think religion meets very human needs, and unless extraterrestrials can provide a replacement for it, I don't think religion is going to go away," and he added, "[i]f there are incredibly advanced civilizations with a belief in God, I don't think [[Richard Dawkins]] will start believing."{{Cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/story?id=5065245&page=1|title=Christian Theologians Prepare for Extraterrestrial Life|last=Keim|first=Brandon|date=2008-06-15|website=ABC News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-10}} Citing a survey by theologian [[Ted Peters (theologian)|Ted Peters]] that showed people were likely to think the discovery of extraterrestrial life would challenge the religious beliefs of other people, but their own beliefs would remain intact, Vakoch told ''[[The Washington Post]]'' that "[i]t looks like we don’t need to be worried about others not being able to handle an announcement of extraterrestrial life.... They’ll do just fine." Vakoch has edited a number of books that examine topics in SETI and astrobiology from multiple disciplinary perspectives, and these books have been reviewed in a number of journals. The review journal ''Choice'' described Vakoch's ''Extraterrestrial Altruism: Evolution and Ethics in the Cosmos'' as "a fascinating speculation into the human condition and what makes us unique or perhaps not unique among all the (hypothetical) intelligences in the universe" and noted that the "book gives a broad perspective on the human condition and will be enjoyable to readers with a wide range of interests,"{{Cite journal|last=Barker|first=T.|date=December 2014|title=Extraterrestrial Altruism: Evolution and Ethics in the Cosmos|url=|journal=Choice|volume=52|issue=4|pages=637}} highly recommending it for "[a]ll academic, general, and professional readers." The same journal said about Vakoch and Matthew F. Dowd's ''The Drake Equation: Estimating the Prevalence of Life Through the Ages'' that "[m]ost chapters are accessible to general readers, while some are at the advanced undergraduate or graduate level. Useful as a novel approach to a popular subject"{{Cite journal|last=Barker|first=T.|date=May 2016|title=The Drake Equation: Estimating the Prevalence of Extraterrestrial Life Through the Ages|url=|journal=Choice|volume=53|issue=9|pages=1347}} and recommended the book for "[a]ll library collections." Vakoch and Albert A. Harrison's ''Civilizations Beyond Earth: Extraterrestrial Life and Society'' was recommended for "[a]ll readers" by ''Choice''.{{Cite journal|last=Barker|first=T.|date=August 2012|title=Civilizations Beyond Earth: Extraterrestrial Life and Society|url=|journal=Choice|volume=49|issue=12|pages=2306}} Vakoch's ''Archaeology, Anthropology, and Interstellar Communication'', published by [[NASA]], was selected by ''[[Library Journal]]'' as a "notable government document" of 2014, saying "[w]hile this is serious scholarship, general readers will appreciate the accessible writing."{{Cite news|url=http://reviews.libraryjournal.com/2015/05/reference/meeting-information-challenges-notable-government-documents-2014/|title=Meeting Information Challenges {{!}} Notable Government Documents 2014|last=Anderson|first=Mark|date=2015-05-26|work=Library Journal|access-date=2017-04-13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} ''DttP, Documents to the People'' wrote that "[t]hese authors have tackled a somewhat controversial subject in a very serious and non-condescending manner, which will be much appreciated by the reader. ''Archaeology, Anthropology, and Interstellar Communication'' is highly recommended for anyone interested in learning about the human quest to communicate with alien civilizations."{{Cite journal|last=Tallman|first=Kathryn|date=Fall 2015|title=Archaeology, Anthropology, and Interstellar Communication|url=|journal=DttP, Documents to the People;|volume=43|issue=3|pages=31}} The same book was cited as an example of budgetary waste by Senator [[Tom Coburn]].{{Cite book|url=http://www.documentcloud.org/documents/1342089-wastebook-2014.html|title=Wastebook 2014 : What Washington doesn't want you to read : a report|last=Coburn|first=Tom|publisher=|year=2014|isbn=9781502941343|location=|pages=30|chapter=NASA Wonders How Humans Will React to Meeting Space Aliens|oclc=899267549}} ''Archaeology, Anthropology, and Interstellar Communication'' included a passage that several news stories took out of context to suggest that NASA had found evidence of extraterrestrial visitation in rock art.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailytech.com/Did+NASA+Book+Say+Rock+Art+Was+the+Work+of+Extraterrestrials+Nope/article34945.htm|title=Did NASA Book Say Rock Art Was the Work of Extraterrestrials? Nope.|last=Mick|first=Jason|date=2014-05-21|website=www.dailytech.com|publisher=DailyTech|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-13}} "Are we alone in the universe? If not, then what might that mean?" begins the ''[[Journal for the History of Astronomy]]'''s review of Vakoch's ''Astrobiology, History, and Society'' and continues by saying "[t]his fascinating volume offers a history of what Western cultures have thought about these questions, a sampling of current work by scientists in astrobiology, and a group of probing essays on how human societies might respond if/when first contact with extraterrestrial life (ETL) or intelligence (ETI) would occur. It is useful to have all this in a single volume - a useful source for scientists, historians, anthropologists, and many other disciplines that concern themselves with these two large questions."{{Cite journal|last=Strick|first=James|date=February 2016|title=Astrobiology and Culture|url=|journal=Journal for the History of Astronomy|volume=47|issue=1|pages=107|bibcode=2016JHA....47..107S|doi=10.1177/0021828615599936}} Vakoch serves as the general editor of the Space and Society series, a scholarly book series published by Springer.{{Cite news|url=https://www.springer.com/series/11929|title=Space and Society|last=|first=|date=|work=Springer|access-date=2017-04-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|issn=2199-3882}} == Space exploration == Vakoch has contributed to the study of space exploration, most notably through books examining psychological dimensions of space travel. [[The Journal of Military History|''The'' ''Journal of Military History'']] noted about Vakoch's edited book ''Psychology of Space Exploration: Contemporary Research in Historical Perspective'' that "[f]or those interested in an overview and synthesis of some of the key issues in the psychology of space exploration, this book provides a great introduction," adding that "[m]ost interestingly to those whose primary interest lies in history, many of the chapters engage the ''history of the psychology'' of space exploration quite well, most notably in the book’s first two chapters."{{Cite journal|last=Hansen|first=James R.|date=January 2012|title=Psychology of Space Exploration: Contemporary Research in Historical Perspective|url=http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/book-reviews/70050833/psychology-space-exploration-contemporary-research-historical-perspective|journal=Journal of Military History|volume=76|issue=1|pages=301}} ''[[Aviation, Space, and Environmental Medicine]]'' observed that "[t]his book is unique in that it places much of the ongoing research and interest in the topic of human behavior and performance in space in historical perspective" and concluded that "[i]t is certainly worthwhile reading for those directly involved in the next phase of human exploration of space as well as those who will witness this phase from the confines of Earth."{{Cite journal|last=Palinkas|first=Lawrence A.|date=2012-07-01|title=Psychology of space exploration|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/asma/asem/2012/00000083/00000007/art00015|journal=Aviation, Space, and Environmental Medicine|volume=83|issue=7|pages=711|doi=10.3357/ASEM.3231.2012}} ''[[Isis (journal)|Isis]]'' wrote that "[t]his diverse and thought-provoking collection represents an important departure for the NASA History Series, a turn from works focused on machines, missions, and management structures to a concern with the smaller group of space sciences interested in human subjects, like space medicine and human factors engineering" and noted that the book "represents an important step in bringing the human-focused space sciences to the attention of a wider audience."{{Cite journal|last=Bimm|first=Jordan|date=2012-01-01|title=Review of Psychology of Space Exploration: Contemporary Research in Historical Perspective, Douglas A. Vakoch|jstor=10.1086/670120|journal=Isis|volume=103|issue=4|pages=812|doi=10.1086/670120}} ''[[Journal of Mind and Behavior|The Journal of Mind and Behavior]]'' noted that Vakoch's follow-up book ''On Orbit and Beyond: Psychological Perspectives on Human Spaceflight'' includes several chapters that address the implications of the increased autonomy that astronauts would have on missions to Mars and Saturn, as compared to orbiting Earth or travelling to the Moon.{{Cite journal|last=Michael|first=George|date=2013-01-01|title=Review of On Orbit and Beyond: Psychological Perspectives on Human Spaceflight|jstor=43854335|journal=The Journal of Mind and Behavior|volume=34|issue=2|pages=197–204}} In an interview Vakoch explained the implications of this increased autonomy: "On missions to Mars, where greater autonomy will be expected of astronauts because of the greater distances, ground personnel should expect that their own roles will change over the course of the mission. Unless ground personnel are prepared, they may feel like they are no longer playing as central a role as they did shortly after liftoff because astronauts are now making more decisions."{{Cite web|url=http://www.nightsky.ws/interview-with-prof-douglas-vakoch.html|title=Interview with Prof. Douglas Vakoch|last=Sanaee|first=Ehsan|date=|website=Nightsky|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-01}} Vakoch explored the positive impact that space exploration can have on astronauts through the [[Overview effect|Overview Effect]]: "At its core, the Overview Effect is about gaining a new perspective about life on Earth, by viewing Earth from a distance. Having survived the flight into Earth orbit, contained in the artificial environment of a space capsule, astronauts look back to their home world with a sense of awe and wonder, appreciative of the fragility of their own planet." He also drew parallels between the Overview Effect and the impacting of discovering extraterrestrial intelligence: "It has often been said that if we ever detect a signal from an extraterrestrial intelligence, letting us know that we are not the only intelligent species in the galaxy, then the differences across terrestrial cultures that seem so crucial today will seem much less important. The differences between Us and Them across cultures here on Earth will seem trivial, when we compare our human commonalities with a new alien Them that evolved independently on another world. The Overview Effect provides a similar sense of perspective for those astronauts who have been able to see Earth from a distance, where the boundaries that we draw on maps are invisible, seeming more like human-made constructions than inevitabilities." "From space, those lines that separate nations are invisible," Vakoch told ''[[Forbes]]'', speaking of a photograph taken of Earth by astronaut [[William Anders]] during the [[Apollo 8]] mission, adding that "the [[Earthrise]] photo implies unity, one planet without boundaries."{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/billretherford/2018/03/07/new-doc-focuses-on-earthrise-photo-apollo-8-flight/|title=New Doc Focuses On Earthrise Photo, Apollo 8 Flight|last=Retherford|first=Bill|date=2018-03-07|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-03-09|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Vakoch told ''[[Wired (magazine)|WIRED]]'' that today's astronauts need capacities that differ from the earliest astronauts: "Historically someone with the '[[The Right Stuff (film)|right stuff]]' was a tough, individualistic person who could explore an unknown frontier with great courage and certainty…. Now, you not only need to be a self-sufficient individual, you need to be able to work with astronauts from other cultures on the International Space Station.... If you’re an American astronaut, very often you’ll be working with people who don’t put as high an emphasis on individualism as the United States does. So, beyond the need for autonomy and independence, there is a greater need for interpersonal and intercultural sensitivity among astronauts."{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2011/07/psychology-right-stuff/|title=Spaceflight Psychology and the New ‘Right Stuff’|last=Venton|first=Danielle|date=2011-07-29|work=WIRED|access-date=2017-05-01|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} "In the early days of space exploration, it really was important to just have the 'right stuff.' If you don’t get along very well with people, you can suck it up for a couple weeks," he told ''Inverse'', adding "[b]ut when you’re talking about a mission that’s going to last for a year, and you don’t have a safe way to vent, that’s going to be a big problem."{{Cite news|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/25720-nasa-hi-seas-mars-mission-colony-astronaut-the-right-stuff|title=Astronauts with People Skills Will Colonize Mars|last=Crosbie|first=Jack|date=2016-12-28|work=Inverse|access-date=2017-05-01|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} "The expectation that astronauts 'have the right stuff' is a big barrier," Vakoch told ''[[The Verge]]'', adding that "[t]hey don't want to admit faults, nor do they want to lose flight status."{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2013/5/30/4377120/nasa-mars-psychology-wearable-sensors-astronauts|title=How to prevent an astronaut bloodbath on Mars|last=Drummond|first=Katie|date=2013-05-30|website=The Verge|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-01}} He said that astronauts on long-duration missions beyond Earth's orbit will face new challenges, telling ''NOW.SPACE'' that "there’s going to be a lot of boredom on a trip to Mars."{{Cite news|url=http://now.space/posts/the-psychological-problems-of-spaceflight/|title=How Will We Deal With the Psychological Problems of Spaceflight?|last=Mann|first=Adam|date=2016-03-26|work=NOW.SPACE|access-date=2017-05-01|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} "Boredom and feeling separation from home will peak during the travel between Earth and Mars and back," he told ''Nightsky''. Vakoch told ''[[Omni (magazine)|OMNI]]'' that despite the challenges of boredom, "[t]he greatest advantage of having humans onboard a deep space mission is that we excel at dealing with the unpredictable."{{Cite journal|last=Baker|first=Sherry|date=Winter 2017|title=Doing Time on a Generation Starship|url=|journal=OMNI|volume=1|issue=74|pages=114|via=}} The [[Mars One]] plan to send settlers on a one-way mission adds additional stresses for astronauts, Vakoch told ''Discovery Channel Magazine'': "Mars One is revolutionary because it overcomes one of the greatest challenges faced by past missions planned for the Red Planet: getting back home safely," adding that "[a]stronauts usually have the comfort of knowing they can return to a safe, familiar environment. However difficult the mission is, there’s an end in sight. Not so for Mars One. By launching off to Mars, they’ll be making a commitment to an unknown way of life that they can never 'unchoose.'"{{Cite web|url=http://docshare.tips/discovery-channel-magazine-india-april-2015_574e2005b6d87f3b438b5d15.html|title=The Mars March|last=Liu|first=Sarah|date=April 2015|website=Discovery Channel Magazine|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-01}} He said there are analogues of people making one-way trips, though "[m]ost people can’t conceive of going on Mars One, because they can’t imagine leaving behind everything they love on Earth," adding that "[i]n reality, this is similar to the loss that all immigrants felt throughout the history of human migrations, whether they were forced to leave home or whether they left voluntarily." At the 2008 annual convention of the [[American Psychological Association]], Vakoch chaired the symposium "To the Moon and Mars: Psychology of Long-Duration Space Exploration,"{{Cite web|url=http://www.apa.org/news/press/releases/2008/08/space-flights.aspx|title=To the Moon and Mars: Psychologists Show New Ways to Combat Behavioral Health Challenges During Long Space Flights|last=|first=|date=2008-08-14|website=American Psychological Association|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-01}} which was identified as a "highlight" of the convention.{{Cite web|url=http://www.apa.org/news/press/releases/2008/05/convention.aspx|title=American Psychological Association 116th Annual Convention in Boston|last=|first=|date=2008-05-12|website=American Psychological Association|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-01}} Vakoch has also examined unmanned space exploration. Commenting on plans to send miniature spacecraft to a nearby star, he told the ''[[International Business Times]]'' that "[b]y sending hundreds or thousands of space probes the size of postage stamps, [[Breakthrough Initiatives|Breakthrough Starshot]] gets around the hazards of spaceflight that could easily end a mission relying on a single spacecraft. Only one nanocraft needs to make its way to [[Alpha Centauri]] and send back a signal for the mission to be successful. When that happens, Starshot will make history."{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/alpha-centauri-mission-stephen-hawking-yuri-milner-plan-send-tiny-spacecrafts-stars-1554511|title=Alpha Centauri mission: Stephen Hawking and Yuri Milner plan to send tiny spacecrafts to the stars|last=Osborne|first=Hannah|date=2016-04-12|work=International Business Times UK|access-date=2017-05-01|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Focusing within the solar system, he commented on NASA's plans to send a lander to Jupiter's moon [[Europa (moon)|Europa]], telling ''[[Gizmodo]]'' that "[t]he top priority of this lander mission will be to search for evidence of life on Europa," adding that "even if that main goal isn’t met, we will learn a great deal about the potential habitability of this icy moon, which will be essential for future, even more ambitious missions."{{Cite news|url=https://gizmodo.com/nasa-plans-to-drill-toward-europas-ocean-in-search-of-l-1792233535|title=NASA Plans to Drill Into Europa's Crust In Search of Life|last=Paoletta|first=Rae|date=2017-02-10|work=Gizmodo|access-date=2017-05-01|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} == Cognitive, cross-cultural, and clinical psychology == Vakoch has collaborated on several empirical studies of human cognition. His research in [[psycholinguistics]] with Lee Wurm explores the perception of speech and emotion from an evolutionary framework,{{Cite journal|last=Vakoch|first=Douglas A.|last2=Wurm|first2=Lee H.|date=1997-08-01|title=Emotional Connotation in Speech Perception: Semantic Associations in the General Lexicon|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/026999397379827|journal=Cognition and Emotion|volume=11|issue=4|pages=337–349|doi=10.1080/026999397379827|issn=0269-9931}}{{Cite journal|last=Wurm|first=Lee H.|last2=Vakoch|first2=Douglas A.|date=2000-03-01|title=The Adaptive Value of Lexical Connotation in Speech Perception|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/026999300378923|journal=Cognition and Emotion|volume=14|issue=2|pages=177–191|doi=10.1080/026999300378923|issn=0269-9931}} with their findings indicating that "speech perception and the affective lexicon" are "closely tied together."{{Cite journal|last=Mullennix|first=John W.|last2=Bihon|first2=Tressa|last3=Bricklemyer|first3=Jodie|last4=Gaston|first4=Jeremy|last5=Keener|first5=Jessica M.|date=2002-09-01|title=Effects of Variation in Emotional Tone of Voice on Speech Perception|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/00238309020450030301|journal=Language and Speech|language=en|volume=45|issue=3|pages=280|doi=10.1177/00238309020450030301|issn=0023-8309}} Vakoch's experimental work with Yuh-Shiow Lee suggests that complex rules are learned better through [[implicit learning]], while simple rules are learned better though explicit learning,{{Cite journal|last=Lee|first=Yuh-shiow|last2=Vakoch|first2=Douglas A.|date=1996-11-01|title=Transfer and retention of implicit and explicit learning|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.2044-8295.1996.tb02613.x/abstract|journal=British Journal of Psychology|language=en|volume=87|issue=4|pages=637–651|doi=10.1111/j.2044-8295.1996.tb02613.x|issn=2044-8295}} with their research suggesting that "implicit learning can be more efficient than explicit learning."{{Cite journal|last=Bitan|first=T.|last2=Karni|first2=A.|date=2004-05-01|title=Procedural and declarative knowledge of word recognition and letter decoding in reading an artificial script|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0926641004000035|journal=Cognitive Brain Research|volume=19|issue=3|pages=230|doi=10.1016/j.cogbrainres.2004.01.001}} Vakoch and the late psychotherapy researcher [[Hans Herrman Strupp]] suggested that the expert understanding of experienced psychotherapists is not adequately captured by manualized psychotherapy,{{Cite journal|last=Vakoch|first=Douglas A.|last2=Strupp|first2=Hans H.|date=2000-03-01|title=The evolution of psychotherapy training: Reflections on manual-based learning and future alternatives|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/(SICI)1097-4679(200003)56:33.0.CO;2-7/abstract|journal=Journal of Clinical Psychology|language=en|volume=56|issue=3|pages=309–318|doi=10.1002/(SICI)1097-4679(200003)56:33.0.CO;2-7|issn=1097-4679}} and they argued that manualized training can impede "the development of clinical judgment and complex reasoning."{{Cite journal|last=Overholser|first=James C.|date=2010-03-01|title=Ten Criteria to Qualify As a Scientist-Practitioner in Clinical Psychology: An Immodest Proposal for Objective Standards|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10879-009-9127-3|journal=Journal of Contemporary Psychotherapy|language=en|volume=40|issue=1|pages=54|doi=10.1007/s10879-009-9127-3|issn=0022-0116}}{{Cite journal|last=Sexton|first=Thomas L.|last2=Dam|first2=Astrid E. van|date=2010-09-01|title=Creativity Within the Structure: Clinical Expertise and Evidence-Based Treatments|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10879-010-9144-2|journal=Journal of Contemporary Psychotherapy|language=en|volume=40|issue=3|pages=177|doi=10.1007/s10879-010-9144-2|issn=0022-0116}} Vakoch's cross-cultural research on the perception of tonal languages with Yuh-Shiow Lee and Lee Wurm suggests that native speakers of tonal languages are better able to discriminate tonal differences than speakers of non-tonal languages,{{Cite journal|last=Lee|first=Yuh-Shiow|last2=Vakoch|first2=Douglas A.|last3=Wurm|first3=Lee H.|date=1996-09-01|title=Tone perception in Cantonese and Mandarin: A cross-linguistic comparison|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF01758181|journal=Journal of Psycholinguistic Research|language=en|volume=25|issue=5|pages=527–542|doi=10.1007/BF01758181|issn=0090-6905}}{{Cite journal|last=Yeung|first=H. Henny|last2=Chen|first2=Ke Heng|last3=Werker|first3=Janet F.|date=2013-02-01|title=When does native language input affect phonetic perception? The precocious case of lexical tone|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0749596X12001052|journal=Journal of Memory and Language|volume=68|issue=2|pages=124|doi=10.1016/j.jml.2012.09.004}} finding "that English listeners had difficulty discriminating Cantonese and Mandarin tones; these authors also found that speakers of the two tone languages were better at discriminating tone contrasts of their own language than of the other language (although they were still better than the English listeners)."{{Cite journal|last=Cutler|first=Anne|last2=Dahan|first2=Delphine|last3=Van Donselaar|first3=Wilma|date=1997|title=Prosody in the comprehension of spoken language: A literature review|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/002383099704000203|journal=Language and speech|volume=40|issue=2|pages=157}} Vakoch's edited volume ''Altruism in Cross-Cultural Perspective'' has been called "a high-quality tool for cross-cultural studies of altruism and beyond”{{Cite journal|last=Grundmann|first=Christoffer H.|date=March 2014|title=Altruism in Cross-Cultural Perspective|url=|journal=Zygon|volume=49|issue=1|pages=268|doi=10.1111/zygo.12073|issn=0591-2385}} and ''[[PsycCRITIQUES]]'' notes that "[t]his book should be of interest to both students and professionals concerned with gaining a broader understanding of altruism in cross-cultural and cross-disciplinary perspectives” and judges that the epilogue "is worth the price of the book alone."{{Cite journal|last=Davis|first=John M.|date=April 28, 2014|title=The Many Faces of Altruism|url=|journal=PsycCRITIQUES|volume=59|issue=17|pages=Article 8}} ''[[PsycCRITIQUES]]'' also identifies limitations of this book: "Although a number of authors address the role of altruism in the context of Eastern religions (Taosim and Hinduism), traditional rituals, and spiritualism, a weakness of the book is that the role of altruism in the Judeo-Christian tradition is barely examined" and "[a]nother weakness is that the chapters are not pulled together very successfully. It would have been helpful to have a final overview chapter to pull the various strands together." Vakoch is a professor of clinical psychology at the [[California Institute of Integral Studies]] (CIIS).{{Cite news|url=https://www.seeker.com/seti-messaging-aliens-extraterrestrial-intelligence-astronomy-science-2265298889.html|title=This Is Why Sending Messages to Aliens Might Be a Good Idea|last=Atkinson|first=Nancy|date=2017-02-16|work=Seeker|access-date=2017-04-23|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} == Ecopsychology and ecocriticism == In conjunction with the annual convention of the [[American Psychological Association]] in 2008, Vakoch assessed people's responses to environmental problems.{{Cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/nation/environment/2008-08-13-green-psychology_N.htm|title=Psychologists determine what it means to think 'green'|last=Jayson|first=Sharon|date=2008-08-14|work=USA Today|access-date=2017-04-11|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} "I think most people recognize we face a severe environmental crisis, but it's hard to deal with that head-on because most people feel helpless to do anything about it," he told ''[[USA Today]]'', adding "[i]f we look at the nature of the problem, it is so big it's hard to know what any individual can do in their own life to make a difference." Vakoch called for additional research into the psychology of environmental issues, saying "[w]e are recognizing that environmental problems have a tremendous impact on many aspects of our lives, but we need a lot more work." He cautioned that "[w]e can't afford to let this increased environmental concern become just another fashionable trend." "Psychologists are increasingly becoming involved in helping alleviate environmental problems," Vakoch told [[CQ Press|''CQ Researcher'']], adding that "[p]sychologists are very experienced in dealing with denial and in helping to frame messages in ways that people can hear the bad news without being paralyzed by it."{{Cite journal|last=Billitteri|first=Thomas J.|date=December 5, 2008|title=Reducing Your Carbon Footprint|url=http://library.cqpress.com/cqresearcher/document.php?id=cqresrre2008120500|journal=CQ Researcher by CQ Press|language=en|volume=18|issue=42|pages=985–1008|issn=1942-5635|access-date=2017-04-17}} "The most important lesson . . . is that there is no 'one size fits all' solution to environmental problems," Vakoch said, adding "[t]o create effective public policies, leaders need to recognize that different people are willing to adopt more environmentally sound behaviors for different reasons. What's compelling for one person will fail for another." ''[[PsycCRITIQUES]]'''s review of Vakoch and Fernando Castrillón's ''Ecopsychology, Phenomenology, and the Environment'' observes that "[a]lthough ecopsychological phenomenology’s lack of shrillness is refreshing and laudable for the intrinsic human values it promotes, the book’s strengths contain its vulnerability. We ''have'' reached some critical tipping points, and we cannot continue with business as usual. The authors in ''Ecopsychology, Phenomenology, and the Environment'' are well aware of this. Rather than making dire warnings, they ask the big questions."{{Cite journal|last=Landon|first=Barbara|date=November 10, 2014|title=Husserl's Remedy: Phenomenology, Ethics, and the Call of the Wild|url=http://psycnet.apa.org/index.cfm?fa=buy.optionToBuy&id=2014-37030-001|journal=PsycCRITIQUES|volume=59|issue=45|pages=Article 2}} This reviewer noted that "[w]hat I liked least about ''Ecopsychology, Phenomenology, and the Environment'' is that all of its authors are North Americans or people living in North America" and "[w]hat I liked most about it, apart from some really beautiful writing, is its mature approach to suffering and the wildness of our nature, as part of the great chain of being. There is a cogent argument that we must address our sense of separateness from the world that holds us. I believe that readers will come away with an expanded sense of identity, and with a sense of calmness about what can be done and how one might go about contributing." Vakoch's books in ecofeminism have been widely reviewed in scholarly journals. The review journal ''Choice'' recommended Vakoch's ''Feminist Ecocriticism'' for “[u]pper-division undergraduates through faculty,”{{Cite journal|last=Utell|first=J. M.|date=February 2013|title=Feminist Ecocriticism: Environment, Women, and Literature|url=|journal=Choice|volume=50|issue=6|pages=1048}} and ''[[Environmental Philosophy (journal)|Environmental Philosophy]]'' called it "an excellent contribution of Post-structuralist Ecofeminist thought on the contemporary liberatory alternatives debate."{{Cite journal|last=Isla|first=Ana|date=2013|title=Feminist Ecocriticism: Environment, Women, and Literature|url=|journal=Environmental Philosophy|volume=10|issue=1|pages=130}} ''[[English Studies (journal)|English Studies]]'' noted that "[u]nfortunately, ''Feminist Ecocriticism'' presents a slightly anachronistic view of ecofeminism, and fails to take into account the many exciting developments taking place in the field since 2000, such as material feminism"{{Cite journal|last=Bracke|first=Astrid|date=2015-05-19|title=Feminist Ecocriticism: Women, Environment, and Literature|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/0013838X.2014.998042|journal=English Studies|volume=96|issue=4|pages=483|doi=10.1080/0013838X.2014.998042|issn=0013-838X}} and "[t]he collection's main flaw is that the essays rarely, if at all, reference scholarly work published since the turn of the century,"{{Cite journal|last=Bracke|first=Astrid|date=2015-05-19|title=Feminist Ecocriticism: Women, Environment, and Literature|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/0013838X.2014.998042|journal=English Studies|volume=96|issue=4|pages=484|doi=10.1080/0013838X.2014.998042|issn=0013-838X}} while "the biggest contribution it makes, which is certainly not unimportant, is to the study of individual works, most notably [[Rachel Carson|Carson]]'s sea books (Sullivan) and ''[[Silent Spring]]'' (Magee)."{{Cite journal|last=Bracke|first=Astrid|date=2015-05-19|title=Feminist Ecocriticism: Women, Environment, and Literature|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/0013838X.2014.998042|journal=English Studies|volume=96|issue=4|pages=484–485|doi=10.1080/0013838X.2014.998042|issn=0013-838X}} The reviewer of Vakoch's ''Ecofeminism and Rhetoric'' for the journal ''Women & Language'' noted that "[t]he material is challenging—in terms of its challenge to popular thinking and conventional scholarship—and, yes, even troubling. However, the authors' reflection on their own work and the frames offered at the beginning and the end of the book provide useful ways of processing the theories and examples, making this is a book to which I will return. ''Ecofeminism and Rhetoric'' provides a strong overview of the field, news ways of operationalizing ecofeminist theory, and an awareness of possible problems with ecofeminism and answers to those critiques."{{Cite journal|last=Senda-Cook|first=Samantha|date=Spring 2012|title=Ecofeminism and Rhetoric: Critical Perspectives on Sex, Technology, and Discourse|url=|journal=Women & Language|volume=35|issue=1|pages=143}} The same reviewer wrote that "[b]ecause ''Ecofeminism and Rhetoric'' provides a strong overview of the field, proffering both classic and innovative ecofeminist critiques, it is appropriate for a variety of audiences ranging from the seasoned ecofeminist to one who has just discover ecofeminism. Additionally, reading the epilogue first will help the selective reader choose how to prioritize the chapters. I will use this book again in projects outside of ecofeminism because the lens is well cultivated and the meta-conversation insightful."{{Cite journal|last=Senda-Cook|first=Samantha|date=Spring 2012|title=Ecofeminism and Rhetoric: Critical Perspectives on Sex, Technology, and Discourse|url=|journal=Women & Language|volume=35|issue=1|pages=144}} ''The'' ''Journal of Ecocriticism'' said of the same book "[i]n many ways, ''Ecofeminism and Rhetoric'' continues the shift toward an interdisciplinary approach in academic publishing. Relevant to many academics, its clear prose, recognizable ecologies, and varied topics attract readers from English departments to the Biological sciences.
